questions.stem_text: What is the primary aim of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning?

options.A: To enable computers to process vast amounts of data efficiently.
options.B: To develop advanced machine learning algorithms.
options.C: To understand the nature of intelligence and cognition to simulate human-like abilities in computers.
options.D: To create complex robotic systems for automation.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which type of reasoning is described as 'jumping to conclusions based on some default assumptions' when information is insufficient, potentially leading to unsound conclusions that may need to be withdrawn?

options.B: Abductive reasoning
options.D: Default reasoning

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: In propositional logic, what is an 'atom'?

options.B: A formula composed of multiple propositions.
options.C: The smallest unit to which a truth value (true/false) can be assigned.
options.D: A symbol representing a numerical value.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following connectives is considered a unary propositional connective?

options.B: Implication (→)
options.D: Negation (¬)

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: A propositional formula F is a tautology if:

options.A: At least one interpretation satisfies F.
options.B: F can be reduced to a Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF).
options.D: Its negation (¬F) is satisfiable.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: What does it mean for a propositional formula F to be satisfiable?

options.A: F is true for all possible interpretations.
options.B: There exists at least one interpretation that satisfies F.
options.D: F can be reduced to an empty clause.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following is equivalent to saying that F entails G (F ⊧ G)?

options.B: F ↔ G is satisfiable.
options.D: ¬F ∨ G is a contradiction.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: What is the total number of sub formulas that can be formed for the propositional formula?
questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: What is a key characteristic of a Herbrand interpretation for a given signature (containing at least one object constant)?

options.A: Its universe is any non-empty set of individuals.
options.B: Its universe is the set of all ground (variable-free) terms of σ, and every ground term is interpreted as itself.
options.C: It always makes all quantified formulas true.
options.D: It must contain at least one function constant of arity greater than 0.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following statements about SAT solvers is correct?

options.A: SAT solvers only accept formulas in Disjunctive Normal Form (DNF).
options.B: SAT solvers decide satisfiability of propositional formulas, often using DPLL.
options.C: SAT solvers can only handle problems with at most 100 variables.
options.D: SAT solvers are inefficient and rarely used in practice.

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Every atom, ⊤, ⊥, and any recursive combination of formulas with connectives are considered valid formulas in propositional logic.

options.B: False

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following statements is a tautology?

options.D: ¬p ∨ p

questions.fusion_notes: Only found in Mistral OCR, used for text and position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following is a key limitation of propositional logic that First-Order Logic overcomes?

options.B: Inability to express relations between individuals and relations
options.C: Inability to use logical connectives such as ∧ and ∨
options.D: Inability to reason with truth values

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following is a valid term in FOL?

options.B: P(x) ∧ Q(y)

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: What is the Herbrand Universe of a signature σ?

options.A: The set of all formulas in σ
options.B: The set of all predicates in σ
options.C: The set of all ground terms of σ
options.D: The set of all interpretations over σ

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: Which of the following is an example of a terminological axiom in FOL?

options.B: Child(John)
options.D: ¬Affects(JRA, Mary)

questions.fusion_notes: Merged from 2 sources, used Vision for text, PyMuPDF for position

questions.stem_text: What are some of the free occurrences of a variable in the below formula?

options.D: None of the above

content_elements.content: Question - 1:  What is the primary aim of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning?
a. To enable computers to process vast amounts of data efficiently.
b. To develop advanced machine learning algorithms.
c. To understand the nature of intelligence and cognition to simulate human-like abilities in
d. To create complex robotic systems for automation.
Question - 2:  Which type of reasoning is described as "jumping to conclusions based on
some default assumptions" when information is insufficient, potentially leading to unsound
conclusions that may need to be withdrawn?
Question - 3:  In propositional logic, what is an "atom"?
a. A logical connective like 'and' or 'or'.
b. A formula composed of multiple propositions.
c. The smallest unit to which a truth value (true/false) can be assigned.
d. A symbol representing a numerical value.
Question - 4:  Which of the following connectives is considered a unary propositional
Question - 5:  A propositional formula F is a tautology if:
a. At least one interpretation satisfies F.
b. F can be reduced to a Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF).
Question - 6:  What does it mean for a propositional formula F to be satisfiable?
a. F is true for all possible interpretations.
b. There exists at least one interpretation that satisfies F.
c. F contains no logical connectives.
d. F can be reduced to an empty clause.

Question - 8: What is the total number of sub formulas that can be formed for the
Question - 9: What is a key characteristic of a Herbrand interpretation for a given
signature σ (containing at least one object constant)?
a. Its universe is any non-empty set of individuals.
b. Its universe is the set of all ground (variable-free) terms of σ, and every ground term is
c. It always makes all quantified formulas true.
d. It must contain at least one function constant of arity greater than 0.
Question - 10: Which of the following statements about SAT solvers is correct?
a. SAT solvers only accept formulas in Disjunctive Normal Form (DNF).
b. SAT solvers decide satisfiability of propositional formulas, often using DPLL.
c. SAT solvers can only handle problems with at most 100 variables.
d. SAT solvers are inefficient and rarely used in practice.

connectives are considered valid formulas in propositional logic.

b. Inability to express relations between individuals and relations
c. Inability to use logical connectives such as
d. Inability to reason with truth values

Question - 15: What is the Herbrand Universe of a signature σ?
a. The set of all formulas in σ
b. The set of all predicates in σ.
c. The set of all ground terms of  σ.
d. The set of all interpretations over σ
